has anyone had to design an app that could theoretically generate an infinitely long navigation back stack? i've been profiling my app for memory usage the last few days and trying to clean up leaks. it seems like RecyclerViews in fragments on the back stack will hold onto ViewHolder references through their adapters, so I've been experimenting with dereferencing data and notifying the RecyclerView adapter in `onDestroyView` for my fragments, then pulling the data back in if the user happens to navigate back to the fragment. but all of this feels kinda clunky and I'm not sure how others would handle it
well if you need to disk back it, mapdb would work well in this situation
but why would you want an infinitely long back stack?
hmm, that's on my to do list a bit down the line
seems like the user wouldn’t want that
for now i'm just re-pulling from the network
it's a reddit client so, you can go to a user profile from someone's comment or submission, then navigate to one of their comments/submissions from their profile, resulting in a cycle
typically once someone's done checking out a page, they'll either go to some sub they want to read (in which case i reset the stack) or tap back to wherever they were before they went on a tangent
hmm so you really need the back history in that case
yup :confused:
well if its just URL’s you can definitely just throw them into mapdb as a set
or if you only care about keeping in memory then a normal set is easy enough
yeah, keeping fragments on the stack shouldn't really eat up too much i would imagine, it was keeping the data referenced in the fragment that was using a lot of memory
i was just wondering if there's some other way of maintaining a stack like that that i'm completely overlooking
you mean the data you pulled from the network?
yeah
using retrofit?
indeed
pretty sure you can add an interceptor? into the okhttp config to overwrite headers which allows okhttp to cache responses for you
then you can continue ‘hitting’ the network and it can decide based on the cache params wether it should return the cache or not
basically in that callback you can manipulate the header attached to the response

hmm, would that be any different than using a `Cache`?
```OkHttpClient client = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
        .cache(new Cache(cache, cacheSize))```
here is an example <http://stackoverflow.com/a/31606496/1286667>

attachments.title: How Retrofit with OKHttp use cache data when offline
attachments.text: I want to Retrofit with OkHttp uses cache when is no Internet. I prepare OkHttpClient like this: RestAdapter.Builder builder= new RestAdapter.Builder() .setRequestInterceptor(new
attachments.fallback: How Retrofit with OKHttp use cache data when offline

text: yeah
i kinda just threw in that line in my okhttp client but never really checked how it works specifically :x

if you enable logging you’ll see it caches based on the http headers.. i dont know what your headers look like but if they have or do not have cache control then you may or may not be caching responses
do most people use ORMs vs hand writing queries?
retrofit has a logging library though, if you turn that on and enable header logging you can easily check it out
ah cool. will look into that then after i finish cleaning up these leaks
thanks for the tips :wink:
yeah np
<@U0CHUGUDN>: yeah, mostly people use ORMs because SQL is boring
although I prefer SQL some times
retrofit 2 removed the logging lib iirc
alright thanks
they did.. same package just with a 2
i'm sure either retrofit or okhttp has logging
oh you add it as a dependency? I just make it as an interceptor
<@U0CHUGUDN>: I would suggest checking out Realm if you are looking for a good middle ground

+1 Realm
but you need to be careful using it tbh
well you can say that for anything
research stuff before using it so you know if its what you need or not
if Realm is the middle ground, what are the other two ends?
well the other end.
yeah but I’ve seen a few cases where people get too tied up in writing models for realm and then when it’s time for something else it’s a PITA to refactor
ormlite is literally sqlite
as far from sqlite that you can get is something like mapdb
none of the 3 are a perfect solution across the board
ok cool thanks.
other things like parse fit in there somewhere too
damn realm looks amazing. esp compared to writing swaths of boring ass sql all day
and dealing w/ sqlite’s bs
yeah.. it’ll be really amazing when you no longer have to extend the realm object
oh then they’ll be numero uno
but they said they’ve got everyone figuring that out like… in april or march last year?
maybe
realm intrigues me, but still not on the hype train yet
not a huge fan of Realm.  seems nice at first, but there’s a bunch of caveats you don’t realize until you start implementing stuff with it
definitely a good start though
yeah realm is great for super simple small apps. But for a complex api/dataset it’s lackluster when you have a bunch of things you CANT do.
the autoupdating thing was weird to me
like a Realm object can update itself automatically or something

also while sql kinda sucks, there are tons of sql wrappers, orm, dao, etc. to make it more tolerable, and there are also simple nosql solutions as well like sharedpreferences, and other nosql solutions.
